conclusion: Problem involves an ideal gas changing states from A to C via B, need to find temperature at state B.
State A is at pressure p0 and volume v0.
State B is at pressure 0.6 p0 and volume v0.
State C is at pressure 0.6 p0 and volume 0.5 v0.
Ideal gas law: pv = nRT; internal energy U = aT.
From A to B, pressure decreases, volume constant, so temperature decreases proportionally with pressure.
Temperature at state A is T0, so TA = T0.
Verification using ideal gas equation: pBvB = nRTB.
Since volume is constant, pBvB = pAvA doesn't make sense, re-evaluate.
Isochoric process: p ∝ T, so TB = T0 × (0.6 p0 / p0) = 0.6 T0.
Internal energy at state B: UB = a × 0.6 T0 = 0.6 a T0.
From B to C, pressure constant, volume decreases, so temperature decreases proportionally with volume.
Verification using ideal gas law: TC = TB × (0.5 v0 / v0) = 0.5 TB.
